Although there were some promising results concerning CQ/HCQ in SARS/MERS, most of these credible pieces of evidence were based on in vitro studies. Only a few clinical studies were available, which were methodologically inferior with small sample size, high dropout rates, variable baseline viral loads compared with monotherapy, and combination therapy of CQ/HCQ and differences in toxicities, which impacted the quality and validity of the results obtained.
30 As the SARS/MERS outbreaks were limited within a particular region and lasted for a short time, there were no follow ups, more extensive observational studies, or controlled clinical trials to support this evidence.
